reviewText: A must have for anyone who enjoys stealth games. Although the graphics are very outdated, this game DEFINED all stealth games that have followed in its footsteps.

Thief is notable for influencing an entire generation of stealth games, and for that reason alone, it deserves to be played. Patience is needed to get comfortable with controls somewhat odd by today's standards and to avoid unnecessary frustration resulting from the player's own carelessness.

Thief 2 is what many consider to be the height of the series, and I tend to agree, however it's very interesting to go back to where it all started.  Aside from a few annoyances (there are far too many zombie/spider filled levels, which negates the use of stealth entirely), this is still an incredibly rewarding and polished experience.  Expect to be challenged, of course.  Death can come very quickly if you don't have any patience, and this is late 90s level design at it's most prevalent so expect to get lost a few times in the surprisingly large maps when you start.  There is no hand-holding here.  On a final note, I find the atmosphere in these early Thief games nothing short of stunning, and certain sections are pretty damn chilling to play through, thanks in part to the sound design.\n\nSo for taff's sake, get on the case and play a part of videogame history already.
Must Play more.
This is a Classic game,  one of my first and favorite games ever !!  awesome to play !

And the level design is just so good, and can be extremely creative...keep an eye out for some of the later missions...they will blow your mind.

The stealth game that all other stealth games should be compared to Thief: The Dark project (later titled Thief: Gold) is one of the most difficult, most balanced, and most well represented stealth action games that I have ever played. Perhaps nostalgia is partially to blame for my love as I purchased the game when it was originally released as well as it's followup Thief 2: The Metal Age and Thief: Deadly Shadows. Thief introduced some of the most well known stealth mechanics still found today such as light/dark with indicators, leaning to avoid detection, smart AI that listen and search for you, and tools to incapacitate and confuse rather than kill your enemies. Add on top of this a three teired diffculty system that not only increases the number of enemies on the map, but also the objectives you must complete, and the AI's intelligence and ability to detect you and Thief shows us what a true stealth game can be if enough effort is put into design rather than art.

Over the years i have played many stealth games, all of them were third person and i always considered that having a third person perspective on stealth games was cheating but that is how almost every single stealth game is so i had to deal with it, i then found Thief, a first person stealth game so i naturally got really excited since it was first person instead of third person and after playing it all i can say is that i cant go back to play third person stealth games, i really cant, Thief is what i always wanted in a stealth game and it is the best stealth game i have ever played and probably will, it is also one of the best games i have played and it definitely goes into my Top 5 of all times.

All third person stealth games do it wrong, Thief is truthfully the only way to stealth.

If you are considering trying a stealth game, I would highly recommend any of the original Thief games. The series is credited with being one of the most influential upon the stealth game genre, and rightly so.

Unlike most first person games, Thief doesn't give you powerful weapons or superhuman abilities. You feel vulnerable. Seeing a guard frightens you; your heart skips a beat when you hear footsteps behind a closed door. And this tension - the knowledge that making a mistake can alert others to your presence or even get you killed - is precisely the appeal of the game. Don't think you can just overpower the guards and carry on, either. You may be able to kill one guard without dying, but you'll probably take a lot of damage in the process, and there's no health regeneration. But, good lord - pulling off a successful heist without being detected is so. damn. satisfying.

The level design is fantastic. The environments range from city streets to ancient ruins to haunted chapels to demonic realms. Seriously. And most levels are very large, so you won't be left hungry for places to explore. You don't have a compass, marker or radar to help you navigate, so you will have to rely on a map and your ordination skills. Some may disagree with me, but I feel this adds immersion that is absent from most modern titles. You need to look around and get a feel" for an area - as you would in the real world when going somewhere for the first time. Learning the patrol routes of guards is vital to avoiding them

Fantastic game. I would've been completely blown away if I first played this in 1998.

The gameplay is pure or simplistic. I needed to pickpocket a guard in the first level but they've never shown me that in the tutorial. So how did I do it? You can just press the use key on the big glowing key they're carrying. :D You can press use" again to drag their unconscious body around. It's very straight forward. reviewText:
If you are considering trying a stealth game, I would highly recommend any of the original Thief games. The series is credited with being one of the most influential upon the stealth game genre, and rightly so.

Unlike most first person games, Thief doesn't give you powerful weapons or superhuman abilities. You feel vulnerable. Seeing a guard frightens you; your heart skips a beat when you hear footsteps behind a closed door. And this tension - the knowledge that making a mistake can alert others to your presence or even get you killed - is precisely the appeal of the game. Don't think you can just overpower the guards and carry on, either. You may be able to kill one guard without dying, but you'll probably take a lot of damage in the process, and there's no health regeneration. But, good lord - pulling off a successful heist without being detected is so. damn. satisfying.

The level design is fantastic. The environments range from city streets to ancient ruins to haunted chapels to demonic realms. Seriously. And most levels are very large, so you won't be left hungry for places to explore. You don't have a compass, marker or radar to help you navigate, so you will have to rely on a map and your ordination skills. Some may disagree with me, but I feel this adds immersion that is absent from most modern titles. You need to look around and get a feel" for an area - as you would in the real world when going somewhere for the first time. Learning the patrol routes of guards is vital to avoiding them

Don't mistake it for being an easy game though. You get a map with scribbles on and it shows you vaguely where you are but you still need to find the way yourself.

I'll definitely be playing Dishonored after this."

The first Thief game is the grandfather of all stealth games. So many other games until then were focused on killing as many enemies on the screen as fast as you could, but Thief was novel because it was focused on remaining invisible, undetected, and most importantly, non-lethal.

I honestly have yet to play any other stealth game that has dedicated the same kind of attention to stealth mechanics as Thief 1 and 2 have. This game takes into account how fast Garrett is going, what material he is walking on, whether something wrong has been noticed, how illuminated you are, what weapon you have out, whether you are crouched or upright, and what direction you are attacking from, in terms of whether a guard or horrifying creature will notice you, and whether your blackjack's hit will be effective.

The amount of tools you must utilize is also quite astounding, ranging from at least five different types of arrows, your lockpicks, your potions, your weapons, and of course, your wits.

The sound for the game is absolute pure euphoria; a simple review alone doesnt really do it justice. You really need to hear to believe, and not just through a YouTube Let's Play, but by actually playing the game and putting on a good pair of earbuds or headphones.

This game has more tense nervewracking gameplay in one hallway than many other stealth" games have in an entire level or several levels. You owe it to yourself to play this masterpiece of a stealth game."

The stealth game that all other stealth games should be compared to Thief: The Dark project (later titled Thief: Gold) is one of the most difficult, most balanced, and most well represented stealth action games that I have ever played. Perhaps nostalgia is partially to blame for my love as I purchased the game when it was originally released as well as it's followup Thief 2: The Metal Age and Thief: Deadly Shadows. Thief introduced some of the most well known stealth mechanics still found today such as light/dark with indicators, leaning to avoid detection, smart AI that listen and search for you, and tools to incapacitate and confuse rather than kill your enemies. Add on top of this a three teired diffculty system that not only increases the number of enemies on the map, but also the objectives you must complete, and the AI's intelligence and ability to detect you and Thief shows us what a true stealth game can be if enough effort is put into design rather than art.
After 15 years, Theif is still a great experience. Very excited for the reboot!

reviewText:
So I started playing this because I like exploration and stealth, and despite it's age this game has those in spades. There are a lot of hurdles to overcome for your experience - The game must be patched to run. The cutscenes still won't display. The graphics are horrendous. The controls are awkward. The locations get a little too nonsensical. The gameplay demands a lots of quicksaves...... Do not expect to be amazed when you start playing. It won't be very fun right away.
That being said, it is a testament to just how fantastic this game is, that it can have all these drawbacks and still be a truly great game. Give it some time and a couple of missions in your reward will be, that somehow, without you realizing it, Thief started to sink into your bones.

You learn how to master the controls, and begin to feel deft at dodging from shadow to shadow. You end up feeling like you taught yourself, you actually learned during the course of the game, how to slink forward, dart out, and whisk away your prize like some kind of master. You creep around as alert as you can, and don't notice it directly, but the enormous levels, the twisting passages, the touches of detail, the remnants of notes left behind, and (most of all) the sounds of the world begin to revebrate and leave you a small piece of a large, strange world, full of secrets and powers beyond your understanding. You don't do it consciously, but you begin to fill in for the graphics. You begin to guess at the mysteries and stories of how these places came to be. There are times when the game environments and the game mechanics rudely interrupt your experience, but most of the time it is a perfect blend that draws out a far richer and more salient experience than most of the games I have ever played.

I never played the two older Thief games before this year, and although I like exploration and stealth, those are my only two biases that might affect my opinion. I highly, HIGHLY, enjoyed it. The expectations I had for this game did not coincide with my actual experience, but it more than redeemed itself by far far exceeding my expectations in other regards. I had no idea ambiance could come through so strongly with such limitations in graphics, sound, AI, and clunky controls. I also hold great respect for it for respecting my intelligence. It did not hold my hand, nor was it devilishly difficult to figure out what to do. Yeah, I wandered around lost and unsure a lot, but there was nothing that was unenjoyable about doing that. The game encourages you to do so, and there is a lot to discover (and steal) while you unlock the greater picture of the mission.  I played slowly and patiently, but I missed a lot of content and could easily play it again for a new expierience. (and probably will)

To summarize:
Gameplay started awkwardly and unfun, but became solid once you are familiar with it.
Sound is not something I care about, but was used masterfully to make this game the excellent piece of work it is.
Graphics are a pain, but the world starts to fill itself in with more than visuals before your mind.
Storyline balances out to solid after averaging out the complaints and the compliments.
The age was a detriment, I won't understate that point.  Even taking that into account, I enjoyed it immesely despite having no history or nostagia-borne fondness it to smooth over my perception.

I highly recommend this game, given that you are patient, don't care about action, do care about a game's background details, and have time to properly become involved in experiencing an entire mission at a time. You could not find a better game for stealth, exploration, atmosphere, memorableness and sheer uniqueness.

Ever think to yourself that Dishonored was not enough of a sneaking game for you? Deus Ex a bit to action packed? Well Thief & Thief 2 are your answer, never before has sneaking been so fully realized as in these two games, and though the graphics haven't aged well the gameplay is truly timeless.

When the first Thief game came out, my brother convinced me to get it.  Glad I did and extremely happy that years later I was able to get it on Steam, and it being Thief Gold at that. I had followed all the games that came out after I had got the first one, but moving from overseas back to the states, they got lost :( so being able to have them available whenever through steam is nice. Only one I did not get was the newest Thief that came out not to long ago. Being an original fan of this series, the new one did not appeal to me personally.

It's a stealth/some what horror game, where you do your best to remain in the shadows and not be seen. At times you may get caught and have to fight, but the main goal is to get what you are looking for, get in wihtout being seeen, and then get out the without being noticed. Also collecting treasures and goodies along the way. The music fits the mood nicely, and depending on which one in the series you are playing or the level, you may come across some pretty weird, eerie stuff along with interesting steampunk style looking contraptions.

One of My favorite things in this game was the passages that are apart of the animated clips before and after the missions. Especially from the Woodsie Lord or the hammerites. Shows the weird but interesting creativity behind the makers of the game.

I feel if you ever played this way back in the day, its worth having for nostalgia, or just because you liked it so much.

For those who have never played it, or played the new one to find out about the old ones, you might not like it so much. The graphics are rough and at times there might be glitching. Sometimes its funny glitches. On some missions I even ran through the end or goofed off with guards chasing me because the way the run or things they say looks hilarious.

I'd suggest if you feel you might be interesting in this game, check on some play throughs of it that are available online first, to make sure it might be something you'll like.

A true classic of the stealth genre where you play as a thief that steals from the rich and keep it all to himself (He got to earn his living too).\nYou are thrown into exciting missions with large and diverse levels, which lets you experiment with different approaches to reach your goal that involve mostly stealing everything that is not glowed to the floor, walls or celling.

Thief Gold was my first Stealth game. I didn't know the simple joy of extinguishing a torch and clubbing some guard unconscious before scrapering with an entire mansions worth of loot in my pocket.

Thief Gold despite it's age and need for a patch (which is easy to download from the looking glass studios Forums) is a stella experience. It is a well paced game with hints and clues to the story scattered through out this richly created world. The first missions get you to grips with the mechanics of the game with all the gadgets and weapons at your disposal.

Garrett is a great playable character, always there to crack wise at certain people or situations to lighten the mood in those slightly stressful missions. In fact there are so many great characters, from the Blackjack fodder to the prisioners.

What I will say is that there are some missions that feel more of a chore than others, especially those concerning the walking dead. These unkillable things were the bane of my play through. It did during those missions become more of a hack and slash type game, despite Garretts terrible combat ability.

Overall though I would highly recomend Thief Gold as a gateway stealth game. It is quite simply a masterpiece.

With these settings, Thief Gold runs very good on my rig.

In Thief, you play as Garret, a legendary thief and a character so famous that even those who never played the series probably heard of him. Garret is the perfect and original thief archetype: Ganancious, egocentric, quick-witted and very, very skilled. Trained by the Keepers, Garret was meant to be an agent for the organization and help to keep order in the city through subterfuge, but he eventually decides that his skills are best employed to steal from others and make a good living out of it. Even though all that Garret ever wanted was to alleviate the rich from their burdens of gold and gems, he finds himself forced to be much more than that when a chain of events place himself at the eye of the storm. The struggle between Order, represented by the Builder, and Chaos, represented by the Trickster, is about to reach its pinnacle and Garret will be right in the middle of it all.

The gameplay is pretty much flawless. Changing the keymapping to your liking is probably a must, since some controls are not as intuitive for not following modern patterns. Once you're accustomed to it, you'll soon find yourself immersed in the single most stealth-driven game that ever was and, hell, probably ever will be. Don't you ♥♥♥♥ing dare using your sword on this game unless there's a immediate threath to your life. Thiefs like Garret never kill and are never seen. If you play the game on expert (which is exactly how the game should always be played), you'll be required to see and do everything without ever killing a human being. That is stealth right there. Walk in the hard wood instead of the carpet and your steps will alert guards. Remain in the shadows with your sword out and the blade will shine and give you away. Shoot an arrow off its target and everyone will hear it hitting the wall. This is how stealth should be done, no quick running around no-scoping teleports and instant magic kills (I'm looking at you, Dishonored). All you have in your inventory are some lockpicks, a blackjack and a few different arrow types, like rope arrows for reaching hard-to-get places or water arrows for squishing out torches. That being said, you should probably know that there will be combat, since there are supernatural creatures walking the world and some of them are very, very violent. This is the reason you carry a sword around.

Graphics are a little outdated, especially on the resolution support department, but mods can easily fix that. All in all, with a little setup time and a little getting used to, you'll be playing the game like a pro and enjoying every second of it one or two hours after buying it, trust me.

Gameplay - 10/10

Replayability - 6/10

One of my most memorable gaming experiences from back in the day....and I only ever played the demo!! That's a fact, but even after all these years that brief experience with this game stuck with me. Just from what little I experienced back then I quickly realized that Thief was far more engrossing and complex then most games at the time of its release and now that I've purchased it and finally played through most of the game up to the time of writing this review, my mind has truly and completely been blown by its level of depth.

The stealth tactics you can make use of, such as water arrows for putting out torches and fires, moss arrows to muffle the noise you make as you slowly walk/crouch towards unsuspecting enemies, rope arrows to more quickly complete objectives or work your way around a tight situation, hiding bodies, etc. all make this an unforgettable experience.

The level designs are pretty complex and extremely atmospheric and there are also some fairly challenging environmental puzzles to solve at times too. Even the voice acting and ambience totally sets the mood for your quest for loot and other more notable goodies as you complete objectives.  Oh yeah, and then there's the strong horror element (some of the ambience plays a role here too, as it perfectly sets the mood for those creepier moments) relating to some of the objects you acquire in the game and enemies such as zombies, spiders (including giant ones), skeletons (well, at least 'a' skeleton that tried to kill me at one point) and also demonic and ghostly-enemies.

Thief is one of the better gaming experiences from an earlier generation. Even after all these years, it still stands out in the crowd and remains one of the best stealth experiences you'll ever have in a game, bar none!

UPDATE (8/8/15): Just beat the game, and if I've learned anything from the many trials and tribulations I faced furing my quest (besides how to properly steal things while being all stealthy and whatnot) it's that Constantine is a major ♥♥♥♥♥♥!

Thief is one of the many master pieces that makes the video game industry still worth defending over the stupid assasin's creed and Call of duty Bullsh*t lately. It is the only game that has really balanced stealth with good combat if you get yourself in a jam.

The game is really old though, so the graphics might take some getting use to, it reminds me of when video games were introduced depth and perception and not a 2D side scroller. The controls are messed up like no other in here though, and-from what I can see- there is no way to change it. It's not that they are stiff or stuff like that, it's just they placed the commands in the most awkward postions on the keyboard.

I've never really understood the story because, as old as this game is, it just throws you into a level and expects you to know what's going on so when something happens I kind of misunderstand and it takes me a minute to realize what just happened. To understand the story you mostly have to read what you are going to do on the current mission, and why.

But what makes up for it is the gameplay and the stealth in this game. Few games today can actually have good stealth and still manage the game with decent combat if you gor yourself in a pickle, Thief puts that right on the mark if you have to run and hide, you can do it. If you need to fight your way out, you can do it.

To accsess this level:
1. Exit the game
2. Fing Thief Gold "USER.CFG" file. Default directory is C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common	hief_gold
3. In "USER.CFG" file add a line starting_mission 16
4. Save the file.
5. Launch Thief Gold -> New Game -> Skip Training.
6. Enjoy"

I love and loved this game. I played it back when it it first came out around when I was 5 or 6 (1998-1999) and even when I go back I am surprised by how advanded the software is on such an old game. The second one is amazing as well. The third one, Deadly Shadows, .... ehh give or take, I mean it is a Thief game and if you care for story get it, I loved it regardless of it's somewhat shoddy gameplay. The newest one, the reboot (forth game), is pretty good as well. Although I will admit it has it's downfalls like being too close in stealth systems to Dishonored, and having a slide system (almost Dishonored teleport system with limitations), and it is still an amazing game, but doesn't provide the same backstory for Garrett. In the old games (this one in particular) there was a reason Garrett was a thief and also how he became a master thief, but in the reboot it is lost.

If you played the new one and are curious to how to old games stack up BUY IT! If you never played any of them but love stealth games BUY IT! If you have have never played a Thief game and have never played a stealth game or are not normally interested in stealth games BUT IT! I promise for $7 you will not be disappointed. This game is worth much more than that due to quality, but for as little as it costs you will never feel guilty you bought it.

I will admit, the graphics quality is subpar in comparison to today's video games, but if graphics quality means little to you and you care more for gameplay and story quality BUY THIS GAME!

Remember how I said SS2 was basically a better and less accessible Bioshock in every way?  This is kind of the opposite.  I'm sure Thief is a great game, but it has the misfortune of being compared to Dishonored nowadays, which is similar in terms of gameplay with the added benefits of being faster-paced and nicer to look at.  Yes, Blink breaks the game in half despite being a core mechanic, but breaking a game in half is, in my opinion, the most fun you can have with a game.  But back to Thief again:  I don't know if I can say for sure that this has necessarily aged poorly, since I've played a number of games with similarly obtuse lean-forward-button mechanics, but rather that these games (DX and SS2 are the first to come to mind) haven't necessarily been improved upon while it seems to me that Thief actually has.

So what merits does it have?  The setting is unique and I wish I could have gotten more into it.  Garrett seems really cool and I might pick up TDS just to see what these parts of the series have to offer.  But this feels to me like I'm playing a fossil.

Of course, if you can get over that hurdle, I'm sure there is something great to be found here.  I absolutely recommend you try this game in case you can appreciate it more than I can.

Thief was the first game to implement the sound system, where different objects make different sounds, and if you're in light, the sensor is yellow and you can be seen. as heck. I would recommend you try Dishonored if youre new to stealth because its a more dumbed down stealth game.

Immensly fun, atmospheric, with a fantastic storyline and universe. Rather challenging with a smart stealth tactic, and really requires the player to be calm, patient (and also load anytime they screw up... which in my case is frequent) and to really listen to where your enemies are (good headphones are a must).

The only thing that personally irritates me a bit is the tedioussness of getting lost, especially in very sprawling areas. However, IMO that makes you feel more like a Thief and in a strange way, makes them game feel more like you're in the shoes of Garret. You're not going in there with knowledge of every nook and cranny, you have to explore, get lost, get lost some more, cry, get lost, reload, start over, get lost again, curse at the screen, and then finally find what you're looking for. It's irritating, but realistic.

I reccomend this to any fan of late 90's games and especially to anyone who likes the stealth genre.

Thief Gold, an expanded version of Thief The Dark Project, is one of the stealth genre's most successful titles.  Although the game is dated, the gameplay is immersive and the level design is immaculate.  Each mission is designed in a way to allow you the use of all of the tools available to you.  Loot is hidden around each mission, interesting sights and text that provides flavor may also be found simply through the exploration of a level.

*****One problem with this version*****

The game advertised is not the game you are buying.  You end buying the original Thief The Dark project and -not- Thief Gold.  Thief Gold had added missions and they are missing from this download.  Something else that is missing are the cut scenes between missions.  Not only are the scenes entertaining, but they help to make you care about the game world and characters while furthering the narrative of the story.  Without these cut scenes, someone knew to the game won't understand everything right away and we are all missing an important part of the experience.

This game is great with stealth and the avenues you can take to complete a level.  You can rob a guard to get the key to a room.  You can use your rope arrow to climb up past a wall to get to another area that unlocks that room.  You can eliminate the guard, although a fight with the guard is not advised.  They can hit hard, as they should.  This is a game about stealth, not to fight with every guard you come across.

Parts of this game do get dull when playing, like exploring large caverns with zombies walking around.  You can sneak past them but they aren't that much of a challange compared to sneaking past guards and stealing items.

If you are big into stealth games, I would highly recommend this game.  I enjoyed it more so than the Metal Gear games.

reviewText: Not hard to see why many consider this a classic. The light-based stealth here was very advanced for its time, and the fantastic art style backs it up well. Several difficulty options add objectives for each level. Options, in terms of equipment and infiltration, are largely left up to the player. However, it falters a bit in several levels, where it seems to play in a far more linear fashion. In these instances, the stealth mechanics, varied arsenal, and occasionally helpful maps feel like an afterthought.\nThe biggest problems are the bugs. Sloppy hit detection, cutscenes that don't play (which often contain valuable pointers), unpredictable AI, and disappearing objects sometimes make it a chore to play. However, the good stealth and area depth more than make up for it.
Thief is a game that you must play if you like stealth games.
Thief Gold is one of the best games that I've ever played, very fun and interactive gameplay along with a great story. If you are into action/stealth games, you should definitely pick up this gem.

Ever think to yourself that Dishonored was not enough of a sneaking game for you? Deus Ex a bit to action packed? Well Thief & Thief 2 are your answer, never before has sneaking been so fully realized as in these two games, and though the graphics haven't aged well the gameplay is truly timeless.

If you are a fan of the series, you should pick up this game when it goes on sale. For me the game was fun to play but mostly for the lore and the story. I started out playing Thief: Deadly Shadows, so playing this is a good way to pick up on what happened before the more graphically intense games. While I would consider this game to be clunky, and dated, the gameplay is still surprisingly challenging, and rewarding. I mostly found myself running through the levels however, just to finish the game, and not taking the full time to sneak around and enjoy the atmosphere. Either way, if you enjoyed any of the other games, I would recommend picking this one up as well.

Thief: the Dark Project, one of the most influential stealth titles out there, is a must play for stealth gamers.
Thief Gold is pretty much the Dark Project with a few missions added to it.
Positives:
+ Great stealth gameplay. Use darker areas to your advantage to sneak by enemies, aided with a wide arsenal of arrows and your trusty club, blackjack. The light crystal, unlike other similar objects in other stealth games, shows you the degree of how hidden you are, rather than show you if you're visible or not.
+ Large, non-linear level design.
+ Difficulty. Prepared for a challenge? Expert will test you if you're a professional thief. No killing, more loot.
+ Your state of mind after listening to hammerites whistling that DAMNED tune for hours.
+ Stephen Russell's voice as Garrett.

Negatives:
- Outdated looks. This can be fixed to some degree with graphical mods.
- Large level design can get you stuck at times.
- New players could find the controls to be uncomfortable. Profiles can be found online for a more modern" control scheme.
- Thieves' Guild. The worst mission in the entire series (not counting the missions in the press-space-to-win reboot). When you get to this point

Graphics are bleh, but oh well, I can see where I'm going and what I need to do. It's pretty fun, just make sure you remap all your key binds or you will have a hard time doing things.

reviewText:
Thief Gold is a first person stealth game. Singleplayer only. Released in 1998.
It's quite old but you can believe me: It's nice and worth a try.

Graphics:     8/10

It's an old game. So I can't compare it with Crysis 3. The textures and effects are really ok.
The most important thing here: They created a really nice atmosphere with textures you would describe nowadays with the word awkward.

Leveldesign:     7/10

Let's split this topic. There are good levels and bad levels.
The bad levels are so confusing that I wish I could erase them for good.
For our luck these levels are fairly rare.
Most levels are really well designed. You have to think and search for the best path
in the shadows hoping to not get detected. Sometimes there are more ways to get to the target location. There are plenty of secrets and loot. I admit that sometimes it's extremely hard to find the correct answer to the riddle and the game becomes frustrating.
To sum it up: 7/10.

Sound:     5/10

On one hand you have really annoying enemy sounds, on the other hand you can locate the enemies' footsteps and the rest gives you a fitting sound ambience. Music is virtually not existent and not necessarily needed in this genre but I miss it.

Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10

You are the thief crawling in the shadows. The game wants you to hide and sneak. And I swear you will do it. Otherwise you will have a really bad time playing the game. The enemies are too strong for you to kill them in combat (most of them). You must use the really innovative equipment to take your enemies down and find the best way to infiltrate. But it takes a long time to get used to the controls and rules" of the game. For example: Killing people with arrows is nearly impossible except you do it from the shadows (1-shot kill). The same thing with the club. Knock people out with one hit from the back or die after trying to kill your enemy face to face. The most important tool is your bow. Use your rope arrows to climb up
date: use water arrows to extinguish the torches
recommended: use the noise arrow to distract enemies
hoursPlayed:
use moss arrows to silence your steps (etc.).

Enemies/AI:     9/10

Ok - now I have to explain. Nine out of ten is really high.
I have to remind you that this game is really old. And it's really amazing that guards don't just ignore dead or sleeping bodies and keep on searching you until they find you. The AI reacts if you miss the shot and I never experienced a real bug. Sometimes the AI has problems with altitude but it's not gamebreaking or noticeable.
So for this time: Awesome!
BTW.: Most undead are dumb like they are meant to be.

Story:     7/10

It's a nice story with unexpected twists. Some people may have a problem with the fact that the story becomes science fictional and doesn't remain realistic. The voice actors for the characters are really fitting and it will never be boring throughout the game. The best thing is that you can hear Garrett's thoughts which makes the chacacter lively.

Critic summary:     7.5/10

Personal fun rating:     8/10     [very good game]

The game is oldschool and one of the first stealth games. And it deserved the name Thief..
I can recommend the game for genre-fans. One warning: If you don't have patience then this is not your game.
One of my favorites. 31h played (one playthrough). Sadly the replay value is low."

reviewText: I alerted some guards by throwing crates. They came for me and saw me but only one decided to fight, and subsequently got bashed in the face by my blackjack, after taking away most of my health of course. The other was caught on a pillar and, thinking I was gone, started to look for me again. I shot him in the face and he ran to get help. Later, I ran into a guard patrolling the halls and ran away (he didn't follow, though). Using my superior intellect, I jumped down a flight of stairs and died. I was on the first level.\n\nThe stealth was good, too. 10/10

reviewText:
Stealthiest game ever
This is the father of all first person stealth games and its goal is not to engage in combat as in many other FPS, but to avoid it and act as a true thief! The sounds your character makes, makes you think about your every step if you don't wanna get caught and the light system which is one of the main point of the game is perfectly done. Levels are massive, and for a game like this, it is perfect.Hide in the shadows to avoid enemies or take them down when necessary. Sneaking at the patrolling guards is really thrilling and sometimes funny when you listen to them talking to themselves :)

I recommend downloading a HD patch! The game looks pretty bad by today's standards. With the HD mod, however, it looks positively gorgeous!

reviewText: I came to Thief late.  As much as it's praised, and that praise is well deserved... it does suffer from a bad control scheme and some of the problems of retro games.  You should rebind your keys immediately, because you KNOW your hand is going to be reaching for WASD.  This is an easy fix, but it does need to be done right from the onset.  But the bigger problem is that the physics have some serious issues.  They were standard, normal issues for all games of the time.  Younger people who can't remember gaming in the 90's, are likely to get severely frustrated with these issues.  I get frustrated with them MYSELF.  It shouldn't take six tries to jump over a one-foot ledge, but it often does.  You shouldn't fall to your death because of the lack of the game's responsiveness, or because your character's toe was in the wrong place and prevented you from getting up on the ledge, but you do.  We used to take these things in stride because it was the best thing we had.  So if you're less than 25, new to gaming, or frustrate easily, you should probably stick to modern games.  But if you're 25+, or if you can take your lumps with old game mechanics issues (die horribly a hundred times, get ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and come back to it later when you've cooled off, and do it on the first try... you know that's how it goes every single time) you'll love this.  The story and narration are great.  I can't wait to go through the whole series!  You do have to keep in mind that this is from 1998, but I would still recommend this to anyone.  Even if you don't enjoy the gameplay, this is one of those games you hear about constantly, and having first hand experience of a classic game is the best thing.  It's like seeing Casablanca, or playing the Ocarina of Time, for a more game-centric comparison.  When you're looking at its flaws, view it critically, like an old horror movie with cheesy effects.  Let it sit heavily on your mind that it was the best they could do at the time, and don't judge it against modern game standards.  Judge it instead, on the merits it had, compared to other games at the time.  By that standard, this game's amazing.

reviewText: An aged classic from a time when games refused to hold your hand, it's a difficult game to recommend in 2015 given how poorly games from that time have aged but past the abstract graphics and slightly clunky mechanics it's pure Gold (pun intended). What a steal.

reviewText: This is one of those games where everything was done right. Great story, great game world, great everything. This is NOT a game where you can just brute force your way down a hall and stealth is there is on the side, just in case. You have to be aware of the lighting, the surface you are walking on, and patting guards as you approach your goals or else you may very well die. The levels are all well-made and interesting with some that are just creepy (Down in the Bonehord anyone?).\n\nI picked it up on sale but would be happy to have paid whatever its original price was. We need more games like this one. At the time of this post, the Theif collection is on sale (Gold, Metal Age, Deadly Shadows, the Thief reboot, etc) but even if all you do is pick up Thief Gold you will be entertained for sometime.

reviewText: I can see why people liked it back in the day. I'll start with the good. It is surprising that a game from the 90's was soo deep with gameplay. There is hiding in shadows, different sounds on different surfaces, big levels, and hiding bodies. Quite complicated and intricate which is nice for an older game. It is fun playing the original game that inspired sneaking around as a new genre. Then there are the problems. With the different surfaces, is is poorly implimented. If you walk on tile or wood or other things, you automatically make a sound, which is unrealistic. While it would make more sound than carpet, you can still be silent on tile. I would use the walk button and slowly inch out on tile while crouched, which in real life would be silent. But since I stepped on tile it automatically alerts the guard the instant my foot touches it. It  is poorly done and not realistic. Sometimes it wont make any sound but the guard will get alerted, which can be confusing.

reviewText: The bad news is that the core gameplay is a frustrating awkward mess. The good news is that everything else, especially the voice acting and writing, is excellent. The worst news is that this is a game, so it suffers greatly from glitchy hitboxes, bugged moving geometry, bizarre lighting, nonsensical audio simulation, muddy controls, and more.\n\nI had fewer issues in System Shock 2, so hopefully Thief 2 will incorporate all those fixes and be the game this franchise deserves.

reviewText:
Continuing along with some older games and series that I've wanted to play for years, I now play the original Thief game (without having played any of the others, so I am going in order) after just playing System Shock 2, which I loved. Unfortunately, I did not love Thief, nor did I really like it, though I came in with high hopes as I knew that the same developers made System Shock 2.

Firstly, I don't mean that the game is inherently bad in many ways. In fact, the majority of the game's design aspects are actually very well done, except for one, which killed the game for me: the level design. Before I get there though, I will first go through everything else I thought about the game, on the positive side:

+ The story of the game was very interesting, even just starting with the first cinematic, which got me excited about the game actually going somewhere.
+ Garrett is a very likable character and had his own unique attitude, unlike a good amount of protagonists (e.g., the one in System Shock 2 had no character to himself).
+ The graphics of the game were decent and didn't bother me, though some things were badly distorted and the mansion in The Sword was ugly.
+ The mechanical design of the game is great. I love all of the different items you can use, including intriguing things like the Moss Arrows. The fact that game properly organizes the stealth depending on the material you are walking upon is good, as some current games don't do such a thing. Simple things like directional combat when swinging the sword is good, which again most games don't do nowadays. And changing the difficulty and indirectly changing the objectives of levels is a great idea to add replayability, extending the levels.

But sadly, none of the above things helped me get over the level design, which was abysmal. The first level was a generic mansion with nothing special about it, but I was like Okay

reviewText: I love the idea of stealth games, but unfortunately this game and many others rely on trial and error. It's especially bad here since the combat system is so clunky and broken. Blocking with your sword only works when the game feels like it, and the hit detection is terrible. So combat should be avoided as much as possible. Sneaking up on a guard and knocking them out works most of the time, but other times they'll hear you even though you're moving slowly on carpet. Sometimes you'll get stuck in the middle of a well lit hallway and hear a guard coming that you can't possibly avoid. The only way to get through the game is to fumble around these terrible maps and memorize where these unavoidable hazards are.

reviewText:
Well here we are. Thief is ♥♥♥♥. Thats the truth it might have been good in the 90's but know it doesn't hold up for many reasons to numerous to name so here a few cons and pros of the game:

Cons
Graphics: The graphics are old thats the best way to say it but to be honest graphics quality doesn't really bother me but i know a lot of people are quite into their graphics so thats why its here.

Map: I have nothing wrong with map screens if they have some sort of sanity put in them but Garrett god bless him decided to draw them by hand badly so the fun of a non-linear world is ruined by having no way of navigating it.

Combat mechanics: Unlike most stealth games nowadays where there is a focus on action over stealth which is good because it gives variety and change to the genre but what makes a stealth game great for me personally is choosing how you would like to carry out your task. Basically whether you want to go in guns blazing or be more sneaky in your execution, Thief doesn't give you this option as the combat mechanics are really bad and trying to fight the guards is like trying to beat a dark souls boss while armed with a wooden stick.

Pros:
Non-linear map: With reference with my map problems this is feature is sort of ruined but i am still going to add it because maybe you can decrypt Garretts map and get enjoyment out of the exploration of these massive maps.

Stealth mechanics: Brilliant, top of the range, amazing.. All words you could use to describe the stealth mechanics: Different materials make varied sounds either loud or soft forcing you to be more careful and thoughtful when you are sneaking through an area, The detail thats gone into the lighting and shadow casting is amazing for such an old game and it really adds to the dark grimy feel of the game but also makes for great stealth moments.


In conclusion. I do not recomend Thief as compared to the stealth games we have now a days (Dishonored and Hitman for example) and i know a lot of people are going to disagree with me but know they are doing it because they are filled with nostalgia and nostalgia can only be felt in people that played the orginal thief so if you are looking for a expansion on the orginial game with the same mechanics and atmosphere then go nuts but, if you are like me and have not played it then i would avoid this game as it doesn't hold up to games like Dishonored (my personal favourite stealth game) and Hitman.

P.S: Feel free to type as many hate comments as you want i am bored and i could use an inane arugument to liven things up.

reviewText: OK ignore the small detail of me having no hours logged. I beat this a long time ago and recently bought the steam version. Ok now Thief is often heralded as one of the best game series of all time. And I will say its a mighty fine series but its had a fair share of stumbles. See when this game first came out it was like the coolest thing since Mario, and that was the first game in the series really didnt have a standard to follow. It was the first of its kind. I mean a game that is built around avoiding enemys? Pfffft blasphemy. But apparently it gained such a following that they made Gold edition. *gasp* More thief content?! See the original Thief had 2 levels cut from it and you know, I can see why they where. And this next statement applys to the entire game. The level design is completly nonsensical. They progress like massive labirynths and tombs, not compounds for the rich. Another gripe I have with the levels are the sewer portions. They focuse on combat and trust me that aint the games high point. If im gonna play a stealth game im going to play a stealth game not resident evil. And overall I see Thief 1 the same way i see Zone of Enders 1. The sequels are much better but if you like the first game cool beans play it. But for a defenitive Thief experience play 2 or 3 not this one.

column19:

The positives:  Great story.  Great voice acting by Stephen Russell portraying anti-hero Garrett.  Ground-breaking stealth play.  Amazing AI.

The negatives:  No third person view.  Dated graphics. Problems running on modern systems.

Some games age well.  Civilization III

reviewText:
Exellent game for a person in love with anything stealth focuesed. Even without any nostalgia value for me, i still love it.

great game\n

Theif Gold is definately one of my favorite games of all time. Although the technology is somewhat dated the developers ingeniously used the concept of stealth to assist the player in maneuvering past the guards without being spotted. If your new to games like these, it will take plently of practice to master. However, if you master the basics and complete your first level, complete satisfaction is guaranteed. Whatever you steal turns into gold so you can purchase items such as broadhead arrows, fire arrows, and health potions. Cool stuff huh?

You are Garret the Thief, battling Mystical Creatures, Undead, Realigious Hammerites, and Normal Everyday Guards, and you get lots of way to kill or get away from them, you could sneak by, run by, or just flat out knock the guy out. My one complaint about the whole game.........Civilians.
The original Thief has become one of my favorite games of all time... The father of all modern FPS-stealth games, with fantastic characters, gripping story and solid gameplay.

Thief Gold is one of the few games of its kind. Even though I can't say I enjoyed every second I played, I consider it a masterpiece. By modern standards, the game is broken. During some stealth missions, you have to stay well hidden, but not because you will fail the mission if you get discovered; the combat system is built on such primitive mechanics that your dignity will be severely damaged.

Yet, what is it so good about the game? Well, everything, even the bad parts. It is incredible how they managed to put everything into a formula that works like a charm. The atmosphere is wonderful and the story is amazingly well narrated.

Do I recommend it? YES. Everyone should try to complete the game at least once, on Normal difficulty level, preferably without a walkthrough.

The game is extremely fun. PLease fix!!!!! but is is still a great game.

This classic is the grandfather of all modern stealh FPS. At least to me it is.\nThe atmosphere and story element of Thief has always felt unique to me and the sequels Thief 2: the metal age and Thief 3: Deadly shadows continues in the originals footsteps of unfolding the saga of Garret the thief in a compelling way. The cinematics are of particular interest for those that enjoy dark medieval settings.

Buy the GOG version. The steam version has compatibility issues along with outdated resolutions. Great game though. Thief 2 is better however, but the 1st is definitely a classic in its own right with a creepy and moody atmosphere. But it fails in one critical area and that is the thieving. My main issue with it, there isn't enough of it in the first game. Pretty soon the game instead goes from excellent theft themed stealth game, to Garret zombie, raptor, demon hunter. Having a few supernatural beasts do add plenty of spooky horror elements, adding to the atmosphere, but they over do it. The cathedral level can burn in stealth game hell. That mission was annoying, unescecary, and frustrating.\n\nMy gripes with the game though are with a few exceptions, minor. This game is a masterpiece, along with 2 and deadly shadows. It was a pioner in stealth gameplay and a fun adventure in its own right. It created a memorable character and made pc gamers like myself, cream thier pants. Buy it, Play it, Love it.

Took 20 hours for me to complete this so it has good hours for single player game from my view. Because of difficulty settings you will get more hours in this game to spent.

Got an ♥♥♥ beating for sucking at stealth.
Why is that a good thing? Because I now know that I never really understood stealth games or how to properly play one until I played this.

If you can get past the old graphics and sometimes clunky movements (it's actually really nice for a game from 1998), the game has some really nice mechanics that make it pretty unique. For example sound and its relation to your surroundings and movements in the game really play a big part in how stealthy you are. The setting and the story is also quite interesting.

And unlike a lot of games that are being released in current and recent times, this game does not hold your hand. It'll teach you the basics of sneaking and moving around, and then leave you to fend and figure things out for yourself. Your character is not O.P'ed. And by that I mean even though you're given a sword in this game, Garrett can't fight for ♥♥♥♥. Which, as bad as that sounds, is great because I think that actually really enhances the gameplay and atmosphere.

This game is definitely replayable.

Using the thief patch that is available online is definitely recommended when playing as it fixes certain glitches and allows for slightly clearer graphics and options.

The first of many games that taught us - not through words, but actions - to hide. Not to fight and be an unrealistic dual weapon wielding juggernaut, but to negotiate your way stealthily through levels, as a true Thief would. Thief is undoubtedly the father to many excellent stealth games such as Splinter Cell, and does not merit the fame or praise it rightly deserves from many.
Also noteworthy is our narrator and protagonist, Garrett - easily one of my favourite protagonists for his little monologues now and again.

Where to even begin. Do you like atmospheric games with the best stealth mechanics in the history of video games? How about smarmy, rogueish, yet extremely likeable protagonists, whose smooth voice etches memories into your mind? How about a stealth game that actually encourages you to behave like you're trying to sneak around, instead of purposely attempting to manipulate bad AI?(Sorry, Dishonored.) The legacy that this series left behind should be enough of a recommendation, but allow me to add my voice to the deafening cries of the masses:\nThis is the best stealth game I've ever played.

As one of the first 3D stealth games, Thief Gold does a surprising number of things really well, even after only 5 missions. Dynamic lighting combines with an amazing stereo sound (get a headset) to create an intuitive atmosphere, where you're sneaking from shadow to cover, nicking things and conking guards on the head. Levels are huge, exploration is huge (no invisible walls), and the tools/arrows you have are large and varied. Top it up with a spooky, tense soundtrack and you have a real gem.

It's not all great: graphics are ofc 1998, enemy AI isn't perfect (enemies don't notice patrolling guards go missing or torches going out), the Steam version doesn't show cutscenes (which is what Youtube's for), you backtrack a bunch, item menu is a bit clunky, but all these minor setbacks don't stop it from being a great game. It takes a while to get into, but if you love nicking someone's bag of coins before whacking him on the head, it's well worth $10.

My main issue with it, there isn't enough of it in the first game. Pretty soon the game instead goes from excellent theft themed stealth game, to Garret zombie, raptor, demon hunter. Having a few supernatural beasts do add plenty of spooky horror elements, adding to the atmosphere, but they over do it. The cathedral level can burn in stealth game hell. That mission was annoying, unescecary, and frustrating.\n\nMy gripes with the game though are with a few exceptions, minor. This game is a masterpiece, along with 2 and deadly shadows. It was a pioner in stealth gameplay and a fun adventure in its own right. It created a memorable character and made pc gamers like myself, cream thier pants. Buy it, Play it, Love it.
A fantastic game that I would recommend to anyone. Incredibly refreshing to go back to a time when games were actually difficult, complex, and deep.

You are Garret the Thief, battling Mystical Creatures, Undead, Realigious Hammerites, and Normal Everyday Guards, and you get lots of way to kill or get away from them, you could sneak by, run by, or just flat out knock the guy out. My one complaint about the whole game.........Civilians.

This is a very old game now, but definitely worth one, or more playtrough. Don't care with the old graphic, and outdated features! Just immerse yourself in the fantasy environment, and follow the storyline, explore the levels, consider it as a middle age adventure, you not going to regret it!
The definitive stealth game,
A stealth game actually done right. Stay in the shadows and keep completely quiet or you're screwed.
This game is flipping impossible. Why do I keep trying. Why.

I absolutely LOVED this game. There is no other series out on the market that really puts you into the shoes of a masterful thief like this one does. I love the stealth and planning required in this game. You are often dropped into the maps with little hint on what to do, but there are usually multiple ways to go about completing a level which is great. It certainly does not hold your hand like modern games do, and because it is old it also runs perfectly on computers and laptops not made for gaming.

If you love the stealth aspect of the game, then higher difficulty settings will work better for you and aso give you more gameplay content to complete. If you can't help but kill some guards/civilians, then the normal difficulty setting is best for you. But the game is still hard even on that mode haha! I definitely recommend learning how to use arrow ropes properly because they will be your best friend in a lot of the later maps/levels.

The only problem I really had with this game is that for some reason to cutscenes wouldn't run on my pc, which was a minor inconvenience because I had to go watch them on youtube. This may not be the case for everyone, but after looking it up I know I'm not the only person who had that issue. However, cutscenes aren't too important if all you care about is the gameplay itself.

Overall, I'd give this game a 9.5/10.

An important game for the stealth/ action genre. Thief is the game that all first person stealth games need to be compared to. Pioneering areas like first person movement, using sound and light as gameplay mechanics and emergent gameplay it arguably spawned an entire genre.\nIf you have any interest in stealth games and want to explore the roots of the genre, then you should really try this game. The visuals and controls are dated, but with a bit of tweaking it's really not much of a problem.

Don't be fooled by the outdated look of this game, for it will be one of the best games you will ever play. It has mechanics of stealth way ahead of its time and it has a complex story once you get past the first few levels. I recomend it for people who love stealth games and need new material to beat and get scared with. Yes you read that right, this game is legitimately freaky. and thats just the atmosphere.

The first of many games that taught us - not through words, but actions - to hide. Not to fight and be an unrealistic dual weapon wielding juggernaut, but to negotiate your way stealthily through levels, as a true Thief would. Thief is undoubtedly the father to many excellent stealth games such as Splinter Cell, and does not merit the fame or praise it rightly deserves from many.
Also noteworthy is our narrator and protagonist, Garrett - easily one of my favourite protagonists for his little monologues now and again.

reviewText: The pioneering title in the stealth genre still holds up to this day. Excellent level design, tense stealth with AI that surprisingly doesn't feel all that outdated and the thrill of theft are all still there, couple it with a great world, mythos and story and you got a great recipe. My only complaint is the over abundance of supernatural elements which can make it feel more like a dungeon crawler at times, but it doesn't hamper the product all that much.\n\nFinal rating 9.4/10

As most of you may know, the new Thief reboot came out not too long ago. In honor of it's release, I am ignoring it entirely, preferring to watch GhostRobo lets-play it and compare it to this, the Thief Gold Edition. Right off the bat, I nearly broke into tears. Not at how well-rendered the worlds were (not very), or how good the voice acting is (not), but because this game is the epitome of something that most modern games are apparently deathly afraid of; having a completely stealth-based game. Most games have certain stealth aspects that you can choose to integrate into your game experience, or forced stealth sequences that your character uses to get his recently stolen items back. Thief is something different, you're a wisecracking medieval pickpocket who turned to his pickpockety ways in order to live in the city that was apparently forged to have conveniently shadowed areas right next to things like guard posts and enough loose change laying around to fund my bottomless pit of desire for nice TF2 weapons. Without stealth, it's hard to beat the game legitimately, but there's something special about it, it's still better than all the Assassin's Creed games are, and ever could be. Proceed to light your torches and grab your pitchforks, Ubisoft fans.

I have high hopes for Thief 2 the Metal Age, as I am playing the series save for the reboot (which from what I have heard I shouldn't bother with) in order.

Stealth defined.

It is this game that spawned all the modern-era stealth genre as we know it. Hide in shadows, don't make loud noises, be sneaky instead of aggressive. Thief does this all well. Very very well. You can go all aggro if you wish, but it will not be easy or satisfying.
The game takes place in a fantasy steampunk setting where magic and myths are very real. You can overhear conversation, break in rooms and read journals. (some are important, most are trivial). This really immerses you into the game and doesn't feel like a static game.

Very well done game they do not mkae them like this anymore.This game is from the days of no hand holding there are no way point" markers or any other form of hand holdiong.You have to read the mission objectives and look at the map and figure things out on your own.Thief has some excellent sound effects they still stand the test of time so many years later.\n\nYou have lots of tools at your disposal variuos types of arrows
recommended: moss arrows which are aimed at noisy floors and spread a patch of moss on the surafce to allow for silent movement

Of course the graphics are very dated but this was cutting edge when it was released.Graphics are not everything despite what the modren gaming industry wants you to think.Thye have thier place but story and gameplay are what is most important and Thief does both very well.You can complete each mission several diffrent ways which adds a lot to replay value.I am the type of player that likes to take my time in a game playing each mission/level the term "speed run" to me is sacrliage.

If you like a good story and stealth type gameplay this is a great addtion to your library."

A instant classic from the days of windows 98 and one of the first well implemented stealth games. Every level has its own character with traps, secret passages, guard, ghouls and treasure scattered through out them. One level you maybe breaking into a fat cats mansion to steal a priceless scepter while the next level find yourself deep in a crypt looking for a magical horn. Each level has a good back story that makes the game feel more like a RPG/Stealth at times though you can't customize your character you customize his equipment for every level. Graphics will be scary to the younger generation (though they do make HD texture packs) for the generation that grew up playing balders gate and deus ex you shouldn't mind them.\n

reviewText: Theif Gold is definately one of my favorite games of all time. Although the technology is somewhat dated the developers ingeniously used the concept of stealth to assist the player in maneuvering past the guards without being spotted. If your new to games like these, it will take plently of practice to master. However, if you master the basics and complete your first level, complete satisfaction is guaranteed. Whatever you steal turns into gold so you can purchase items such as broadhead arrows, fire arrows, and health potions. Cool stuff huh?
A thief would steal gold, its true.

Thief, the game that pretty much started the sneak-genre. With a heavy doze of nostalgia I'm gonna say that it still has its charm and is still very fun even though its nearing 15 years of age.

Of course gaming have come a long way and gamedesign have changed a lot since this was released and the leveldesign range from brilliant to painful.

Well, its a good game, but honestly if you didnt play this when you were young you probably will have a hard time getting into it. But maybe pick it up in a sale and have a go at it. :)

Deep, riveting and almost head-crushingly intense at times, Thief The Dark Project is one of the best stealth games ever made. The punishing difficulty and the occasional combat-orientated level may throw some players off, but Thief is otherwise a masterpiece of stealth gameplay.

reviewText: This game...aside from a few issues, such as graphics (It was made in '98, give it some credit), controls, and small AI problems, I loved this game. The stealth mechanics are nearly seamless, with attention to sight and sound. Not only that, but this game does not pit you as a hero, per se; you are more of a man after one thing: gold. How you get it is up to you. You are given lots of options; you could murder or knock out every guard you come accross and charge through the level, worrying about your health (as your character isnt the best fighter), or you can go the stealth route and sneak past, pickpocketing guards for keys and looting treasure.\n\nTLDR: Game's good bro 9.7/10

You shouldn't pass it up if you even remotely enjoy being stealthy. 8/10

As most of you may know, the new Thief reboot came out not too long ago. In honor of it's release, I am ignoring it entirely, preferring to watch GhostRobo lets-play it and compare it to this, the Thief Gold Edition. Right off the bat, I nearly broke into tears. Not at how well-rendered the worlds were (not very), or how good the voice acting is (not), but because this game is the epitome of something that most modern games are apparently deathly afraid of; having a completely stealth-based game. Most games have certain stealth aspects that you can choose to integrate into your game experience, or forced stealth sequences that your character uses to get his recently stolen items back. Thief is something different, you're a wisecracking medieval pickpocket who turned to his pickpockety ways in order to live in the city that was apparently forged to have conveniently shadowed areas right next to things like guard posts and enough loose change laying around to fund my bottomless pit of desire for nice TF2 weapons. Without stealth, it's hard to beat the game legitimately, but there's something special about it, it's still better than all the Assassin's Creed games are, and ever could be. Proceed to light your torches and grab your pitchforks, Ubisoft fans.

Even with a multitude of handy tools at your disposal, Your mission to break in and steal valuables is by no means easy. It forces you to be creative to survive with minimal hand-holding outside of the tutorial level. This game has clever level design and capable AI to top it off.

I can safely recommend this to newcomers and Thief veterans who already owned the original version (like me) alike, because it is a decent release with a much needed compatibility patch to make it run on modern rigs and current Operating System.  Also, it contains some new levels and bug fix not present in the original release of Thief.

Released in 1999 Thief Gold is the re-release of 1998's Thief: The Dark Project the wonderful game from the sadly now defunct Looking Glass Studios.  Originally Thief was known as Dark Camelot and intended to be an action RPG type of game and you can see throughout this game where they recycled content from that original game - ie medieval influenced missions.  it later morphed into Dark Project when they found that the stealth aspect (championed by Paul Neurath) was a lot more entertaining and that a game involving stealth and thievery would be a better option.

Rather than being a straight re-issue of the game it was an early form of what we now know as GOTY editions. It includes 3 extra levels: The Mage Towers, The Thieves Guild and Song of the Caverns.  In addition to extra missions it also tweaked the standard missions some minor tweaks in most and then a couple of levels receiving reworking notably The Sword (added more area - ie Little Big World), Undercover (story changes), The Lost City (enemy and story changes) and Down in the Bonehoard is retextured.  Furthermore Thief Gold moves the version up to 1.37 from T:DP's final version of v1.33.  On the old discs you also got a preview of Thief II and of course the additional mission the Blooper Reel (Lord Baffords Manor featuring entertaining bugs and humorous content)

At present the cut scenes do not function on some systems, notably Windows 7, there are various work arounds available - they can be found over at ttlg.com (file is called Tfix_1.18c) or if you so wish you can always Youtube the Thief cut scenes.  I highly recommend you watch the cut scenes, not only do they advance the story and reveal a lot of twists and turns related to it but they are also beautifully crafted and remain a joy to watch.

The concept of Thief is simple, achieve the mission objectives by the use of stealth.  Stealth in this game pertains to use of shadows, sound and movement.  To aid you in this you have a light gem in the lower section of the screen that indicates the amount of light you are currently exposed in.  Sound is highly important and was one of the first games, if not the first where sound was just as important as what you could see.  Footsteps on varied surfaces, the sound of patrolling guards and ambient noise all add a rich and extra layer of gameplay.  You need to take these elements and work within them or bend them to your favour to achieve your objectives.

The game is set within The City, a steampunkish type era, like the Victorian era on the cusp of industrialisation.  The City itself is moody, bleak and dangerous, the perfect playground for the adventurous. There are several factions within The City all vying for control, the mysterious Baron of the City remains aloof, a figure of power and control but not involved directly.  The ambience of The City is beautiful and it's success is largely due to the presentation of The City, both aurally and visually. The story that unwinds also fleshes out The City.

Comparisons can be made to Dunwall from Dishonoured and Dishonoured does indeed play like a Thief game and has that ambience, albeit the focus is on assassination and not on stealth and theft.  Dunwall though is the victim of politics that goes up to the highest level, The City feels more alive though.   There is no apocalyptic plague sweeping the streets and the highest power is not overtly tyrannical but the various factions do give layers" to The City
date: it feels like it has more depth and soul than Dunwall ever had
recommended: it is an entity in itself.\n\nThe visuals are nothing exciting but they are effective enough.  The sound though is truly a thing of sublime beauty.  This is the first game where it was essential to have sound enabled and if possible to have a dedicated sound card (that again has kind of died out thanks to integrated sound on motherboards).  From the fabulous sound ambience to the classical Loot sound it is all very stylised and very integral to the Thief experience.  It must be said that the talents of the voice actor for Garrett
hoursPlayed: Mr Stephen Russell truly stand out as one of the greatest in gaming. He gives Garrett the very jaded
voteText: near misanthropic character that makes the game feel so immersive.\n\nGarrett feels like what you would expect to be a product of hard life within The City it is conveyed wonderfully.  It is wonderful to hear Garrett go into his internal monologues during missions
helpfulPercent: throwing story
votesHelpful: character and enjoyment at you.  Be warned though after sneaking through a level only hearing footsteps and ambience you may jump off of your chair in fright the first time his voice unexpectedly booms out at you.\n\nThe difficulty levels change objectives and throw in variables such as not killing anyone and collecting a certain minimum amount of loot. At the easier difficulty levels it can be easy to roll in and kill all the enemies in a level
votesTotal: but by far the biggest challenge is to play on the Expert setting and try to adhere to the rules of Ghosting - ie don't let anyone see you
votesFunny: leave things as you found them (except for things you need to loot to achieve the objectives)
commentsCount: don't knock anyone out even relock doors you pass through etc.. By and large the rules of Ghosting are self-imposed
column16: a fun challenge to yourself
column17: but a rewarding one.  Consider the missions (levels) to be a big playground at your disposal.\n\nThe controls are standard controls for the era and you may find you will want to tweak them to match what you are used to playing today - ie alternating strafe and lean keys for instance and changing the walk and backwards buttons etc.  Combat is straightforward - use your bow to snipe targets or to shoot a variety of specialty arrows - water arrows to douse torches
column18: moss arrows to soften the noise on surfaces
column19: rope arrows to climb to other areas
column20: fire arrows to destroy things
column21: broad head to kill enemies/make a noise
column22: noisemaker arrows to create a distraction etc..  The Sword play is simple
column23: space to block and primary attack to swing the sword.  Hold it down for a stronger strike. By far the most useful tool though is the Blackjack.  This item is used to render guards unconscious.  Slip up behind a guard raise your blackjack and then bring it down upon their head.  Then get rid of the unconscious body - be aware that placing a body near a fireplace or in even a small amount of water will probably result in death to the unconscious party - bad if you are trying to achieve a no-kill objective.  So while dumping that body into an unlit fireplace may seem great

Thief: The Dark Project is one of three game released in 1998 that gave birth to the stealth based genre and basically laid the foundation for future games to come. Unlike modern stealth games which give you the option of fighting your way through mobs, you almost always want to stay hidden and strike from the shadows. Mobs usually take quite a few hits to go down and your character Garrett, although an adequate fighter in his own right, is quite squishy and will usually go down really quick. That's not to say that the direct combat method should be avoided, it's actually quite doable, however, the clunky combat system, questionable collision detection and lack of an aiming reticle makes direct combat more trouble than it's worth.\n\nThe stealth mechanics I thought was innovative although can be quite laughable at times. Thief incorporates a cover system that allows you to conceal yourself in dark, shadowy areas. A light gem" indicator tells you how visible you are to the mobs around you
recommended: a flaw with the system is that enemy vision AI is dependent on the light gem
hoursPlayed: so you can literally stand right in front of a mob and as long as your light gem is indicating that you're hidden
voteText: they won't notice you and will walk past you as if you were invisable. Sound also plays a part in stealth with AI responding to noises you make such as footsteps or the impact of a thrown item against a wall. Different floor types can affect the way your footsteps sound. Your gadgets are mostly based around stealth are actually quite creative. Water arrows lets you douse torches to darken a room
helpfulPercent: moss arrows lets you create soft patches on the ground to walk on to dampen your footsteps
votesHelpful: etc. Level design is organic and open ended similar to Deus Ex
votesTotal: giving you more than one way to reach your destintion.\n\nIf you can get over the outdated graphics (and if you're a real gamer
votesFunny: you should) you'll find that Thief still manages to hold it's own even by today's standards. Solid gameplay
commentsCount: well written story and the atmospheric soundtrack all blend well to create an immersive experience. The game is lengthy enough to keep you playing for quite a while. It's challenging but not unfairly difficult and the lack of a mini map
column16: way points or instant checkpoints shouldn't detract you. It's actually a nice throwback to a time when video games didn't hold your hand as much as it does now. Completing it is very rewarding

column18: patience is a trait that most gamers nowaday lack."

Thief is the pinnacle stealth game. Presumed to be the first stealth title to use shadows as a form of hiding from the enemy. The controls still hold up to this day, but the graphics haven't aged well, some of the characters look like coneheads. Either way, the dialog from the npc's is fantastically written and the plot development of Garret's venture as a professional Thief starts from basic robberies to religion conspiracy. A worthwhile title of being one of the greatest stealth games of all time.\n\n9.3/10
My favourite game of all time. Astonishing atmosphere, storytelling, soundtrack and gameplay. Must buy.

This is easily one of the greatest single player games I've ever played. Yes the animations and graphics are ancient, but the level design, the atmosphere, and the sound are without equal. I would recommend this to anyone who wants a solid single player experience, regardless of whether or not you like stealth games. It's just that good.
